Find the curve defined by the equation
\[r^2 \cos 2 \theta = 4.\](A) Line
(B) Circle
(C) Parabola
(D) Ellipse
(E) Hyperbola

Enter the letter of the correct option.

ost_step.1: Using trigonometric identities, rewrite the left side as \[\cos 2 \theta = 1 - 2 \sin^2 \theta\] so \[r^2 (1 - 2 \sin^2 \theta )=4,\]which simplifies to \[r^2 - 2 r^2 \sin ^2 \theta =4.\] Step 2: Rearrange terms and complete the square:\begin{align*} r^2 &=4 + 2 r^2 \sin^2 \theta \\&= 2 + 2 r^2 (\sin^2 \theta + 1)\\ &=  2 + 2 [(\sin \theta + 1/2) ]^2\\&=( 1/\sqrt{2} +\sin \theta)^2\end{align*}Note that $(\sin x-\csc x)^2 =\cot^2 x.$ Thus our solution represents a line whose angle makes up half the difference between angles associated with opposite roots; thus it corresponds to one root each time around the unit circle. Hence Option (A):Line It follows directly since the graph formed above passes through origin when plotted along polar axis keeping constant radius equal zero.<|end_of_sol
ost_step.2: Convert into rectangular coordinate system using equations \(x = r\cos \theta\) and \(y = r\sin \theta\).
ost_step.3: Squaring both sides of \(x = r\cos \theta\) and \(y = r\sin \theta\), we get \(x^2 = r^2\cos^2 \theta\) and \(y^2 = r^2\sin^2 \theta\).

Substituting \(\sin^2 \theta = 1 - \cos^2 \theta\) into the second equation yields \(y^2 = r^2(1 - \cos^2 \theta)\). Adding these two equations together results in \(x^2 + y^2 = r^2\).
